title: Inspiring the Next Generation: R-Ladies Melb at ‚ÄúIt Takes A Spark‚Äù Conference
description:
**Welcome to our first event for 2025!**

How do we spark curiosity in coding, data science, and epidemiology among high school students? For the last several years, R-Ladies Melbourne has been running an engaging and interactive 80-minute workshop at the It Takes A Spark STEM Education Conference, introducing students to R, data visualisation, the power of clear science communication and concepts in epidemiology.

In this talk, Dionne will share insights from our experience delivering this workshop‚Äîhow we designed it, the challenges we navigated, and the impact we've seen. We‚Äôll also discuss key lessons learned, how we've adapted our approach, and our vision for the future of inspiring young minds in STEM.

Whether you‚Äôre an educator, mentor, or simply passionate about making STEM more accessible, join us to explore how we can continue to empower the next generation of data scientists and communicators.

See you there,
R-Ladies Melbourne üíú

title: [ONLINE] Tidy Data, Weighted Insights: Analyzing Complex Survey Data in R
description:
Please join us for a meet-up with co-authors Stephanie Zimmer, Rebecca Powell, and Isabella Vel√°squez on **Analyzing Complex Survey Data in R**! This meet-up is being co-organized with **[R-Ladies RTP](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-rtp/events/305348585/)**.

**Topic:** Surveys are powerful tools, but to ensure the accurate interpretation of results, they require specific analysis methods. With the \`srvyr\` package and \`tidyverse\` family of functions, we are able to analyze survey data with weights to derive meaningful results. Our new book, Exploring Complex Survey Data Analysis Using R, goes through how to do this step-by-step. You can view the book here: [https://tidy-survey-r.github.io/tidy-survey-book/](https://tidy-survey-r.github.io/tidy-survey-book/).

**Agenda:** This webinar will start with an overview of the importance of weighting in survey analysis and the framework for conducting survey analysis in R. We will highlight examples from the book, including how to calculate means and perform t-tests. Knowing that publication-ready tables are important, we will show you how to efficiently create reproducible tables using your final weighted data! We will end with time for Q&A and discussion.

**Prerequisites:** There are no prerequisites. All members are encouraged to attend.

**Code of Conduct:** R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. For more information, see the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/coc/).

title: Choices and challenges in restoring a {renv} project
description: The {renv} package helps you create reproducible environments for your R projects. The distinction here between ‚Äúhelps you create‚Äù vs ‚Äúcreates‚Äù is important. {renv} provides a framework for project specific package documentation and installation, but it is up to the user to make decisions on when and how to maintain the project when updating R or specific packages. In this meet-up, we will live demo an attempt to restore an older {renv} project and discuss the choices and challenges {renv} users confront.

title: Interactive R, Python, and Shiny in the Browser with Quarto and Shinylive
description:
Discover new ways to share R, Python, and Shiny projects using Quarto Live and Shinylive, no server required!

These tools bring R, Python, and Shiny applications to life directly in the browser. Your audience can open a web page and instantly run code or interact with Shiny apps without needing any setup.

Quarto Live allows you to embed interactive code blocks, exercises with hints and solutions, and dynamic visualizations within static HTML documents. Powered by WebAssembly, it brings interactivity to your Quarto documents.

Shinylive transforms Shiny apps into fully browser-based experiences.
In this talk, you‚Äôll learn how to use these tools to create engaging, interactive documents, dashboards, and educational content that anyone can access, even if they do not have R or Python installed. I look forward to seeing you there!

We‚Äôll also explore key concepts such as data collection, cleaning, analysis, visualization, and machine learning, while highlighting R‚Äôs role in the Data Science ecosystem.

Whether you're a beginner or looking to enhance your skills, this session is the perfect starting point to dive into R‚Äôs vast community and resources! üöÄ

title: Cluster analysis in R
description:
In our next meetup we will welcome [Theresa Scharl-Hirsch](https://forschung.boku.ac.at/fis/staff?name=TheresaScharl-Hirsch) for an **introduction to cluster analysis and validation in R**. Bring along your laptop to follow the presented examples and for some hands-on exercises!

**Cluster analysis** groups data based on similarities without relying on predefined labels, making it valuable in marketing, healthcare, social media and fraud detection. Unlike classification, which uses labelled data to assign data points to predefined categories, clustering works with unlabelled data to reveal hidden patterns.
**Cluster validation** ensures that the groups identified are meaningful using metrics such as compactness and separation, while visualisation tools such as scatter plots and dendrograms help to interpret the results. Common methods such as K-means, hierarchical clustering and model-based approaches are tailored to different data structures and objectives.

Durante el taller, aprender√°s a utilizar algunas de las funciones de cada librer√≠a para realizar validaciones habituales sobre conjuntos de datos en formato tabular.

**A qui√©n est√° dirigido:**
Este taller est√° pensado para personas **con experiencia en R** que quieran conocer herramientas de validaci√≥n de datos disponibles en este lenguaje de programaci√≥n.

**Qu√© necesito para participar del taller:**
Para poder seguir la parte pr√°ctica del taller te recomendamos tener previamente instalados los programas [R y RStudio](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/) y los paquetes **tidyverse, pointblank, data.validator, assertr y validate**.

title: From Data to Docs: Harnessing Quarto for Dynamic Reporting
description:
In this webinar, **"From Data to Docs: Harnessing Quarto for Dynamic Reporting,"** Gwynn will take us into the powerful features of Quarto, a versatile tool for creating data-driven documents, reports, and presentations. Expect hands-on demonstrations showing you how to seamlessly integrate data analysis, visualization, and narrative in a single workflow.
You'll learn how to create stunning reports easily, automate document generation, and export to multiple formats, such as HTML, PDF, and Word. By the end, you'll be equipped with practical skills to enhance your reporting process and boost your productivity, making your data insights more accessible and impactful!

title: [Book club] Happy Git: Forks, Pull Requests, and Merge Conflicts
description:
Effective version control is essential for reproducible and collaborative data science. This online session will guide participants through key concepts from the *[Happy Git with R](https://happygitwithr.com/)* book, focusing on **[Daily Workflows](https://happygitwithr.com/time-travel-see-past), part 2 (Chapters 30-34)**. Participants will learn how to collaborate effectively using Git and GitHub. Key topics include forking repositories, making pull requests, managing remotes, and handling merge conflicts. By the end of the session, attendees will be able to contribute to open-source projects, sync changes across different repositories, and troubleshoot common collaboration challenges.
Whether you're new to Git or looking to refine your workflow, this session, the fifth in the R-Ladies book club series, will equip you with actionable strategies to integrate version control into your R programming routine.
**When:** **Tuesday February 18 from 17:00 - 18:30 CET**
**Who:** The session will be presented by Josefina Bernardo from [R-Ladies Amsterdam](https://bsky.app/profile/rladiesamsterdam.bsky.social).
**Where:** Online

title: R vs Python for Data Analytics: A Comparative Walkthrough
description:
Ebuwa Evbuoma-Fike is a Senior Data Scientist with over 8 years of experience driving impactful data-driven solutions in healthcare and civic tech. Passionate about improving health outcomes, especially for underserved communities, she excels in developing and implementing sophisticated data analyses, from complex machine learning models to insightful reporting.

She has a proven track record of success in both the public and private sectors, collaborating seamlessly with cross-functional teams to address critical challenges and optimize operational efficiency. Her expertise spans data engineering, predictive modeling, and translating complex technical insights into actionable strategies for leadership.

This workshop will introduce R users to the Python ecosystem for everyday data analysis tasks. We'll explore core Python concepts and libraries, comparing them to familiar R tools. You'll learn how to perform common data analysis operations in Python, such as data manipulation, exploratory data analysis (EDA), and data visualization. This hands-on session will provide you with a solid foundation to start using Python for your routine data analysis needs, expanding your analytical toolkit.

title: 15th Annual Symposium for Women and Gender Minorities in Math (cross-posting)
description:
R-Ladies Irvine is very excited to cross-post this **Symposium for Women and Gender Minorities in Mathematics in Southern California**. The symposia serves to nurture relationships between mathematicians in Southern California and provide a framework for mentoring. These relationships can facilitate mathematicians branching into new areas of mathematics, an exploration of the variety of ways of contributing mathematically to society and the profession, and the maintenance of a healthy balanced life. The symposia can be particularly valuable for junior faculty planting roots in Southern California.

You are invited to come and, if you like, give a talk! We would especially like to encourage women and gender non-conforming mathematicians. Talks should be 15 minutes long. Many people may want to give a talk on results they have already obtained, but expository talks describing a problem of interest, and interesting things you are trying in your classrooms are also welcome. In particular, graduate students are encouraged to give a talk even if they don't yet have their own results.

The keynote speaker will be Alissa Crans from Loyola Marymount University. There will be a career panel and plenty of opportunities to chat and get to know each other.

The symposium is **free** and meals will be provided but participants are asked to register. For more information and to register, please go to the website:
[https://sites.google.com/fullerton.edu/wimsocal2025/](https://sites.google.com/fullerton.edu/wimsocal2025/)

Directions and parking:
[https://sites.google.com/fullerton.edu/wimsocal2025/parking-and-directions](https://sites.google.com/fullerton.edu/wimsocal2025/parking-and-directions)

**Important Dates:**

* **January 10, 2025 (Friday)**: Deadline for talk and poster abstract submissions.
* **January 16, 2025 (Thursday)**: Deadline for non-presenter registration

title: [ONLINE] Daily workflows and remote setups with Git (R-Ladies book club)
description:
Effective version control is essential for reproducible and collaborative data science. This online session will guide participants through key concepts from the *[Happy Git with R](https://happygitwithr.com/)* book, focusing on **[Git remote setups](https://happygitwithr.com/remote-scenarios-intro)**[ ](https://happygitwithr.com/remote-scenarios-intro) and **[Daily Workflows](https://happygitwithr.com/workflows-intro)**. Participants will learn how to configure remote repositories, manage connections between local and remote projects, and adopt best practices for seamless collaboration using Git and GitHub. Through practical demonstrations, we will cover common daily Git operations, including committing, pushing, pulling, and resolving conflicts, ensuring a smooth and efficient workflow for R projects. Whether you're new to Git or looking to refine your workflow, this session, the fifth in the R-Ladies book club series, will equip you with actionable strategies to integrate version control into your R programming routine.

**When:** **Tuesday February 4 from 17:00 - 18:30 CET**
**Who:** The session will be presented by Kylie Ainslie from R-Ladies Amsterdam.
**Where:** Online

title: R package creation made easy: Introducing {fusen}
description:
Do you want to learn how to develop R packages from scratch? This new R-Ladies Cologne series is just for you! Together, we‚Äôll walk through **every step of package development**, from writing your first function to submitting your package to CRAN.

To launch this series, we‚Äôll dive into **{fusen}**, an innovative package that turns R Markdown files into fully functional R packages‚Äîalmost like magic! ü™Ñ

Here‚Äôs how it works:

* Write your code into R Markdown chunks.
* Label the chunks.
* Let {fusen} handle the rest!

In just a few simple steps, your package will be on GitHub, with all the necessary tests and documentation.

#### Special Guest: S√©bastien Rochette

We‚Äôre thrilled to have S√©bastien Rochette, the **creator of {fusen}**, as speaker in the kick-off meeting of this package development series. With over a decade of experience in Tech and Data Science, S√©bastien Rochette likes to help users exploit the full potential of collaborative workflows to reduce maintenance and tedious activities (such as documenting your package!).

***

### Event Details:

üìÖ Date: 31.01.2025
üïí Time: 16:30pm CET
üìç Location: Online (access details will be shared with RSVPs)

We can‚Äôt wait to see many of you there! Let‚Äôs build packages together. üí™üë©‚Äçüíª

***

To stay up-to-date with our future events, make sure to also follow us on Bluesky (@rladies-cologne.bsky.social) and Fosstodon (@rladies_cologne@fosstodon.org)

*This workshop is part of the R-Ladies Cologne series on "Toolbox for Reproducibility", where we dive into tips, tricks, and techniques on how to adhere to best standards and make our code and workflows reproducible.*

title: Data Federation and R
description: Analysing big health data requires research workflows that balance computational efficiency with strict data governance, particularly relevant to healthcare data sources. This talk explores how the R programming language can be used to build reproducible and scalable research pipelines using R. We will also look at R capabilities that enable Federated analysis of health data. Attendees will gain practical insights into developing, deploying, and running R-based pipelines to process sensitive data securely and efficiently, while generating actionable results.

title: Lunch&Learn: {targets} with Irena Papst
description:
Do you ever find yourself starting with a simple analysis script only to end up wrangling a thousand line behemoth? Are you sick of wasting time re-running long scripts from start to finish, just to make sure everything is up-to-date? Are you (haphazardly?) saving objects to file because they take a long time to generate? There‚Äôs got to be a better way!

Enter {targets}, an R package used to build reproducible, efficient, and scalable pipelines. {targets} can free you from many common analysis management tasks so that you can focus on the analysis itself. In this session, I‚Äôll introduce the {targets} package and share how I‚Äôve used it to streamline my work. I'll also highlight some tips and tricks that I've learned from my experience with the package over the last two years.

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group (on a Wednesday)
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

At this event, we'll revisit one of the Tidy Tuesday datasets from December 2024 on the National Highway Traffic Flow dataset. You can read more about it here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2024/2024-12-03/readme.md and see some previous analysis of the data here: https://webtris.nationalhighways.co.uk/.

Agenda (all times in ET):
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:15 pm #tidytuesday
7:15 - 7:30 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out [this blog post](https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and [the main repository page](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: üíú From R to Python to R üíú
description:
What happens when #Rstats and #Python collide for an evening of learning, laughter, and connection? Let‚Äôs find out together! üéâ

Join us as Courtney shares her journey through the challenges and triumphs of analyzing single-cell sequencing data. Beginning with her go-to tool R, she faced difficulties managing data from nearly a million cells. This led her to Python, discovering new strategies and gaining valuable insights. Ultimately, she then returned to R, leveraging her expertise for the final stages of data visualization. This talk highlights the interplay between R and Python, showcasing lessons learned and practical tips for R coders learning python and python coders learning R.

But that‚Äôs not all ‚Äì there will be games, plenty of pizza üçï, and lots of chances to connect with fellow enthusiasts. Don‚Äôt miss the fun at the Microsoft Reactor in Redmond brought to you by **R-Ladies Seattle, PyLadies Seattle, and Seattle AI Workshops**. See you there! üöÄ

**Speaker Bio**
Courtney Armour PhD is a Bioinformatician at the U of Washington, School of Medicine. She uses her computational expertise to analyze changes in gene expression associated with asthma and kidney disease. She is passionate about reproducible workflows, data visualization, and helping others learn to code. When not at the computer, Courtney enjoys going on adventures with her high-energy German short-haired pointer.

title: introducci√≥n al uso de rgee
description:
Uriel de Jes√∫s Mendoza Castillo nos dara el primer taller de este a√±o 2025!

El taller introduce a rgee, una interfaz de R para Google Earth Engine (GEE), una potente plataforma de computaci√≥n en la nube con un extenso cat√°logo de im√°genes satelitales y datos geoespaciales. rgee permite a estudiantes e investigadores analizar y visualizar datos geoespaciales de manera interactiva, combinando el potencial de R con la capacidad computacional de GEE. Adem√°s, facilita la transici√≥n de usuarios de GEE en JavaScript a R, maximizando el uso de herramientas y bibliotecas del ecosistema R.

title: Deathly Dataviz: How public health dashboards can backfire
description:
***"..., and what can we do instead."***

Can risk ratios be risky? Can visualizing health disparities make them worse? Can our design choices influence these unhealthy backfire effects?

Explore how health dashboards can backfire and what ethical, effective design looks like. Perfect timing as *health equity is more important than ever*!

In this talk, we‚Äôll explore the social impacts of visualizing inequality and disparities in social outcomes. Drawing on Eli‚Äôs IEEE VIS research, we‚Äôll uncover how popular dataviz practices‚Äîlike bar graphs of group mortality risks‚Äîcan unintentionally reinforce harmful misbeliefs, with real-world consequences for the populations being visualized.

Through thought-provoking examples and actionable insights, this session will examine how dataviz intersects with social justice. Learn practical strategies to critically evaluate your designs and adopt approaches that amplify equity instead of exacerbating disparities.

Whether you‚Äôre a health communicator, social scientist, or data enthusiast, this talk offers valuable insights for anyone working with data about people.

Join us to discover how thoughtful design can transform data into a tool for equity and understanding.
